P.FONT: Strong bass line. Serious. Dark. Incidental transforming music in the treble section. The bass holds the rhythm.
Techno circus music. Percussion based. Upbeat bass line.
My first task would be to get the beat and meter to merge, so that they flow from one to the next. I would then get the harmonic sections to evolve from the first piece to the second.

I would need to work out the tempo of each part so that I can slowly change the tempo from one to the other, to keep the beat fairly constant. I would have to work out the meter of each. The meter seems simlar, so there would not be as much to work with there. The melodies would have to be merged. I would try and find instruments that are similar in timbre to cross with. Both have a bass line, so that is an easy target to create a transition. Both have a kayboard, but the styles are quite different. The sustained notes, and longer sequences would over time become shortened until they matched that of the second piece. The horn in the second piece is quite strong, and would need to integrated in a slow manner, perhaps the incidental treble sounds can be shortened until they become a honk. This would also involve a change oin timbre.

Strong sounds that identify the piece are harder to work with. People notice them the most. So if they do not work, then it is doomed to failure. The first piece has a dominant bass line, and an interesting ascending chord progression. The second also has a dominant bass line and odd sound effects. Those are the features I would look at first.

The source doesn't start from its original state. It starts off transposed, which was not expected. Kind of disconcerting. The bass line was interesting. it sounded like four seperate patterns, each one evolved slightly from the one before it, until it sounded like the target. I think the morph is too fast. It jumps from one style to the other too quickly. It gets quite quirky in the middle, kind of wrong, but it still seems functional, although harder to dance to.
Smoothness creates a good subjective response. The smoother it is, the more favourably I would look upon it.

It was fairly effective, but I would probably want the morph to occur in more discrete steps. There seems to be a pattern that is quite discernible. It sounds like a 4 bar pattern. If this was made smaller, with smaller changes made between each pattern I think it would sound smoother. The more I listen to it the better it sounds, which means my ears are adjusting to the style, probably as I listen more carefully and follow each instrument through seperately, and apperciating it better. Each instrument is fairly continuous, albeit with large steps. Initial response though says to make it smoother for a more favourable response.
Change in bassline
The bass is the dominant musical feature. When the bassline changes it is very noticeable.
Change in bassline
As well as the bass line changing there is a treble descending line.
Change in bassline
Change in bassline

It depends on the audience. It would be palatable by many people, especially in a computer game, in a main stream music show it would not be so, because it is unexpected, and a bit quirky. Mr Bungle fans would like it.
If I had only 5 minutes I would remove some of the notes. Around the transition areas I would remove some notes to kind of spread the change and reduce the impact of the next transition.
I would make the transition longer, spread it over double the number of bars.
nice. The breakdown works well. It is a lot smoother than the last morph. It sounds a lot more "right".
I percieved it in a better light - I liked it more :)
I think the smoothness really helps to make it more effective.
the changes still occured in 7second blocks like the previous example.

it would be acceptable by most people, especially in a computer game, where the gamer is used to music changing. The change was subtle enough to not concern a dance crowd, although perhaps still a little quirky.
I would stretch out the morph time. It would give the audience more time to adjust to the change.
dark, slow, intense. it sounds right.
Jazzy, upbeat. Sounds right, in a jazz way :)
speed up tempo, evolve the timbre. slowly change key

Slowly increase tempo. Exchange instruments one at a time so the timbre evolves from one type to the other. The bass and drums would need to be changed the slowest (most subtly), as they will have the strongest effect on the audience reaction.
The minor to major key change will be the hardest part to deal with, because that changes the entire feel of the piece more than anything else.
following through on the quirkiness of the jazz theme really helped that morph. it definately changes from a dark to ahappy piece. It sounds mostly right.
good effect, there are a couple of odd spots which I questioned, but not until the third or fourth listen. The first time around I was impressed.
smooth
change in density
a bit rough
timbral changes
ok
slowly speeding up.

it would be palatable. In a game context it might be useful for indicating the character status, and would be useful morphing from sad to happy music. It would only work in a commercial scene if you wanted to change the mood of the audience, as I feel there is emotional content here that may be sidtracting for the audience.
morphs are too fast. I like slower evolutions.
I didn't like the new parts jumping in like that in the treble area. It is interesting, but it just sounds too wrong, like someone is practicing music over the top of some other music.
negative
not favourable.
the timbre of the trumpet(?) seems distracting.
good
more drums
ok
change in bass timbre
perhaps not mainstream. The two sources sound like they are competing against each other too much.
I would pull out the trumpet synth.
I would redo it.
weird, wrong. Sounds like the composer didn't even listen to the music when they wrote it. Happy crappy.
also sounds a bit wrong, not as bad as the other however. Too many accidentals. sad.
I would turn down the job and tell them to come back when they write something worth working with.
If I really had too.....I would evolve the string line into the bass line, increase the density of the bass line, making the notes shorter. The guitar part could evolve into the high string part.

I already had a negative response to the sources, so i am bias towards more negativity. the middle section with both parts combined however didn't sound as bad as I expected it would, it was the highlight of the piece :)
negative.
the changes totally changed the flow and density of the piece. The thick longer part in the middle sounded nothing like either and held some musical interest, from ana analytical view point.
odd
new instruments
i like this part
multiple droning instruments, that work well together.
ok
the bass line notes length is shortened

it would work with retro gamers, but not many other people. I just imagine it as a musical piece used in a cheap computer game on an 8 bit, 4 audio track computer system, which has tried top crassfade from one game scene to another.
I would mute it all, and tell them there was no other option available! I would perhaps get rid of the treble lines, and just work with bass and drums.
I found the middle part the best part. I would dump the rest, and compose a piece based purely on the middle of the morph.
jumpy, but workable. It still doesn't sound quite right.
It wasn't all that smoth, but in in a larger sense it was..... it brought in parts eary and prepared the listener, so although it had jumps they seemed smaller.
unexpected, but worked ok.
introduction of additional melody line
confusing
a lot of loose ends from different parts.
nice
reduction in instruments. drums introduced, adds stability.
ok
bass line reintroduced
It may work with a select audience, not totally mainstream. I think the rhythm and drum is the key to this piece of music.
introduce the drums earlier, reduce the number of instruments.
use different source material.
inbetween, happy, not totally right. Too many drums.
upbeat, slow but strong. sounds right.
I would remove instruments until it sounded more like the second part.
I would reduce the musical parts of the first part very quickly, then I would go about changing the timbre and melody, slowly evolving it into the second part.
It was okay. It sounded pretty right. The two parts were much more similar than the previous examples so a morph should have been quite smooth.
It was quite smooth. It had a positive effect.
okay, a bit jumbly
key/melody change.
okay
more key/melody change?
good
reduction of instruments
It could work at a more mainstream dance venue. If the individual styles work there, then the morph would also, as it does move well from one piece to the other.
I would remove the vibes.
I would make the transition longer and work with a smaller number of instruments at any one time.
it works okay. it retains it's happy mood throughout.
good. The drums drive this morph.
okay
introduced melody
ok

smoother

reduce the hats.
I would reduce the drums sooner. In fact I would reduce all the data sooner.
I have probably been exposed to all types of music, but I lean more towards pop, classical, folk, rock, and metal.

I think you need to have more musical variety. All the music seemed to come from similar scenes. Some music was unfamiliar in style and sounded wrong from the beginning, which made it haredeer to hear it sound right when it was reused.
3+ hours - i lost count after a while :) I lietened to the music too much :)
